member.name: T:GroupDocs.Parser.Templates.TemplateTable
member.summary: Provides the template table.

remarks.para: There are two ways to define a table:

list.item: Using class. In this case the table is defined by its position on the page: rectangular area, columns and rows separators.
Using class. In this case the table is detected automatically by algorithms with set parameters. See class for more information.

member.name: M:GroupDocs.Parser.Templates.TemplateTableLayout.MoveTo(GroupDocs.Parser.Data.Point)
member.summary: Creates a new layout with the same size, separators and position in the .
member.param: The position of the new layout.
member.returns: A new layout with the same size, separators and position in the .

example.para: This functionality allows to move Table Layout.

For example, a document has tables on each page (or a set of documents with a table on the page). These tables differ by position and content, but have the same columns and rows. In this case a user can define object at (0, 0) once and then move it to the location of the definite table.

If the table position depends on the other object of the page, a user can define object based on template document and then move it according to an anchor object. For example, if this is a summary table and it is followed by details table (which can contain a different count of rows). In this case a user can define object on template document (with the known details table rectangle) and then move object according to the difference of details table rectangle of template and real document.
method returns a copy of the current object. A user can pass any coordinates (even negative - then layout will be moved to the left/top).

member.name: T:GroupDocs.Parser.Templates.TemplateTableParameters
member.summary: Provides parameters for the table detection algorithms.

remarks.para: There are two algorithms to detect a table:

list.item: Allows to detect a table in the rectangular area with set columns. This algorithm is useful for simple tables (without merged columns) and provides more accurate detection.
Allows to detect a table in any place on the page. This is a more complex algorithm. It can detect tables in any place on the page. Additional parameters help to detect a table more correctly.

remarks.para: In some cases when algorithms can't detect a table or do it in non-accurate way class is used.

member.name: T:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType
member.summary: Represents the file type. Provides methods to obtain list of all file types supported by GroupDocs.Parser.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.Unknown
member.summary: Represents unknown file type.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.DOC
member.summary: Files with .doc extension represent documents generated by Microsoft Word or other word processing documents in binary file format. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.DOT
member.summary: Files with .DOT extension are template files created by Microsoft Word to have pre-formatted settings for generation of further DOC or DOCX files. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.DOCX
member.summary: DOCX is a well-known format for Microsoft Word documents. Introduced from 2007 with the release of Microsoft Office 2007, the structure of this new Document format was changed from plain binary to a combination of XML and binary files. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.DOCM
member.summary: DOCM files are Microsoft Word 2007 or higher generated documents with the ability to run macros. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.DOTX
member.summary: Files with DOTX extension are template files created by Microsoft Word to have pre-formatted settings for generation of further DOCX files. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.DOTM
member.summary: A file with DOTM extension represents template file created with Microsoft Word 2007 or higher. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.TXT
member.summary: A file with .TXT extension represents a text document that contains plain text in the form of lines. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.TEXT
member.summary: A file with .TEXT extension represents a text document that contains plain text in the form of lines. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.ODT
member.summary: ODT files are type of documents created with word processing applications that are based on OpenDocument Text File format. These are created with word processor applications such as free OpenOffice Writer and can hold content such as text, images, objects and styles. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.OTT
member.summary: Files with OTT extension represent template documents generated by applications in compliance with the OASIS' OpenDocument standard format. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.RTF
member.summary: Introduced and documented by Microsoft, the Rich Text Format (RTF) represents a method of encoding formatted text and graphics for use within applications. The format facilitates cross-platform document exchange with other Microsoft Products, thus serving the purpose of interoperability. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PDF
member.summary: Portable Document Format (PDF) is a type of document created by Adobe back in 1990s. The purpose of this file format was to introduce a standard for representation of documents and other reference material in a format that is independent of application software, hardware as well as Operating System. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.HTM
member.summary: Files with HTM extension represent Hypertext Markup Language for creating web pages for display in web browsers such as Google Chrome, Internet Explorer, Firefox and a number of others. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.HTML
member.summary: HTML (Hyper Text Markup Language) is the extension for web pages created for display in browsers. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.XHTML
member.summary: The XHTML is a text based file format with markup in the XML, using a reformulation of HTML 4.0. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.MHT
member.summary: Files with MHT extension represent a web page archive format that can be created by a number of different applications. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.MHTML
member.summary: Files with MHTML extension represent a web page archive format that can be created by a number of different applications. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.XML
member.summary: XML stands for Extensible Markup Language that is similar to HTML but different in using tags for defining objects. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.MD
member.summary: Text files created with Markdown language dialects is saved with .MD or .MARKDOWN file extension. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.FB2
member.summary: Files with FB2 extension are FictionBook 2.0 eBook files that contains the structure of the eBook. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.CHM
member.summary: The CHM file format represents Microsoft HTML help file that consists of a collection of HTML pages. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.EPUB
member.summary: Files with .EPUB extension are an e-book file format that provide a standard digital publication format for publishers and consumers. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.XLS
member.summary: Files with XLS extension represent Excel Binary File Format. Such files can be created by Microsoft Excel as well as other similar spreadsheet programs such as OpenOffice Calc or Apple Numbers. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.XLSX
member.summary: XLSX is well-known format for Microsoft Excel documents that was introduced by Microsoft with the release of Microsoft Office 2007. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.XLSM
member.summary: Files with XLSM extension is a type of Spreasheet files that support Macros. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.XLSB
member.summary: XLSB file format specifies the Excel Binary File Format, which is a collection of records and structures that specify Excel workbook content. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.XLT
member.summary: Files with .XLT extension are template files created with Microsoft Excel which is a spreadsheet application which comes as part of Microsoft Office suite. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.XLTX
member.summary: Files with XLTX extension represent Microsoft Excel Template files that are based on the Office OpenXML file format specifications. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.XLTM
member.summary: The XLTM file extension represents files that are generated by Microsoft Excel as Macro-enabled template files. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.XLA
member.summary: The Excel 97-2003 Add-In, a supplemental program that is designed to run additional code. Supports the use of VBA projects.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.XLAM
member.summary: The XML-based and macro-enabled Add-In format for Excel 2010 and Excel 2007. An Add-In is a supplemental program that is designed to run additional code. Supports the use of VBA projects and Excel 4.0 macro sheets (.xlm).

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.CSV
member.summary: Files with CSV (Comma Separated Values) extension represent plain text files that contain records of data with comma separated values. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.TSV
member.summary: A Tab-Separated Values (TSV) file format represents data separated with tabs in plain text format. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.ODS
member.summary: Files with ODS extension stand for OpenDocument Spreadsheet Document format that are editable by user. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.OTS
member.summary: The OTS files contain template files used by the OpenOffice spreadsheet application.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.NUMBERS
member.summary: Files that contain the .numbers file extension are files that are created by the Apple iWork Numbers spreadsheet application.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PPT
member.summary: A file with PPT extension represents PowerPoint file that consists of a collection of slides for displaying as SlideShow. It specifies the Binary File Format used by Microsoft PowerPoint 97-2003. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PPTX
member.summary: Files with PPTX extension are presentation files created with popular Microsoft PowerPoint application. Unlike the previous version of presentation file format PPT which was binary, the PPTX format is based on the Microsoft PowerPoint open XML presentation file format. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PPS
member.summary: PPS, PowerPoint Slide Show, files are created using Microsoft PowerPoint for Slide Show purpose. PPS file reading and creation is supported by Microsoft PowerPoint 97-2003. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PPSX
member.summary: PPSX, Power Point Slide Show, file are created using Microsoft PowerPoint 2007 and above for Slide Show purpose. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.ODP
member.summary: Files with ODP extension represent presentation file format used by OpenOffice.org in the OASISOpen standard. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.POT
member.summary: Files with .POT extension represent Microsoft PowerPoint template files created by PowerPoint 97-2003 versions. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PPTM
member.summary: Files with PPTM extension are Macro-enabled Presentation files that are created with Microsoft PowerPoint 2007 or higher versions. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.POTX
member.summary: Files with .POTX extension represent Microsoft PowerPoint template presentations that are created with Microsoft PowerPoint 2007 and above. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.POTM
member.summary: Files with POTM extension are Microsoft PowerPoint template files with support for Macros. POTM files are created with PowerPoint 2007 or above and contains default settings that can be used to create further presentation files. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PPSM
member.summary: Files with PPSM extension represent Macro-enabled Slide Show file format created with Microsoft PowerPoint 2007 or higher. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.OTP
member.summary: Files with .OTP extension represent presentation template files created by applications in OASIS OpenDocument standard format. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.MSG
member.summary: MSG is a file format used by Microsoft Outlook and Exchange to store email messages, contact, appointment, or other tasks. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.EML
member.summary: EML file format represents email messages saved using Outlook and other relevant applications. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.EMLX
member.summary: The EMLX file format is implemented and developed by Apple. The Apple Mail application uses the EMLX file format for exporting the emails. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PST
member.summary: Files with .PST extension represent Outlook Personal Storage Files (also called Personal Storage Table) that store variety of user information. Learn more about this file format here

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.OST
member.summary: OST or Offline Storage Files represent user's mailbox data in offline mode on local machine upon registration with Exchange Server using Microsoft Outlook. Learn more about this file format here

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.ONE
member.summary: File represented by .ONE extension are created by Microsoft OneNote application. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.ZIP
member.summary: ZIP file extension represents archives that can hold one or more files or directories. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.SEVENZ
member.summary: 7z is an archiving format for compressing files and folders with a high compression ratio. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.RAR
member.summary: Files with .rar extension represent archive files that are created for storing information in compressed or normal form. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.TAR
member.summary: Files with .tar extension are archives created with Unix-based utility for collecting one or more files. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.GZ
member.summary: Files with .gz extension are compressed files created with gzip compression application. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.BZ2
member.summary: Compressed file using Bzip2 algorithm.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.TIF
member.summary: TIF, Tagged Image File Format, represents raster images that are meant for usage on a variety of devices that comply with this file format standard. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.TIFF
member.summary: TIFF, Tagged Image File Format, represents raster images that are meant for usage on a variety of devices that comply with this file format standard. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.JPG
member.summary: A JPG is a type of image format that is saved using the method of lossy compression. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.JPEG
member.summary: A JPEG is a type of image format that is saved using the method of lossy compression. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PNG
member.summary: PNG, Portable Network Graphics, refers to a type of raster image file format that use loseless compression. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.GIF
member.summary: A GIF or Graphical Interchange Format is a type of highly compressed image. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.BMP
member.summary: Files having extension .BMP represent Bitmap Image files that are used to store bitmap digital images. These images are independent of graphics adapter and are also called device independent bitmap (DIB) file format. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.ICO
member.summary: Files with ICO extension are image file types used as icon for representation of an application on Microsoft Windows. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.JP2
member.summary: JPEG 2000 (JP2) is an image coding system and state-of-the-art image compression standard. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.JPF
member.summary: JPEG 2000 (JPF) is an image coding system and state-of-the-art image compression standard. Designed, using wavelet technology JPEG 2000 can code lossless content in any quality at once. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.JPX
member.summary: JPEG 2000 (JPX) is an image coding system and state-of-the-art image compression standard. Designed, using wavelet technology JPEG 2000 can code lossless content in any quality at once. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.JPM
member.summary: JPEG 2000 (JPM) is an image coding system and state-of-the-art image compression standard. Designed, using wavelet technology JPEG 2000 can code lossless content in any quality at once. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.J2C
member.summary: JPEG 2000 (J2C) is an image coding system and state-of-the-art image compression standard. Designed, using wavelet technology JPEG 2000 can code lossless content in any quality at once. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.J2K
member.summary: JPEG 2000 (J2K) is an image coding system and state-of-the-art image compression standard. Designed, using wavelet technology JPEG 2000 can code lossless content in any quality at once. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.JPC
member.summary: JPEG 2000 (JPC) is an image coding system and state-of-the-art image compression standard. Designed, using wavelet technology JPEG 2000 can code lossless content in any quality at once. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.DIB
member.summary: A DIB (Device Independent Bitmap) file is a raster image file that is similar in structure to the standard Bitmap files (BMP) but has a different header. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.WMF
member.summary: Files with WMF extension represent Microsoft Windows Metafile (WMF) for storing vector as well as bitmap-format images data. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.EMF
member.summary: Enhanced metafile format (EMF) stores graphical images device-independently. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.WEBP
member.summary: WebP, introduced by Google, is a modern raster web image file format that is based on lossless and lossy compression. It provides same image quality while considerably reducing the image size. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.DJVU
member.summary: DjVu, pronounced as dj vu, is a graphics file format intended for scanned documents and books especially those which contain the combination of text, drawings, images and photographs. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.CGM
member.summary: Computer Graphics Metafile (CGM) is free, platform-independent, international standard metafile format for storing and exchanging of vector graphics (2D), raster graphics, and text. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PCL
member.summary: PCL stands for Printer Command Language which is a Page Description Language introduced by Hewlett Packard (HP). Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PSD
member.summary: PSD, Photoshop Document, represents Adobe Photoshop's native file format used for graphics designing and development. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.DCM
member.summary: Files with .DCM extension represent digital image which stores medical information of patients such as MRIs, CT scans and ultrasound images. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PS
member.summary: PostScript (PS) is a general-purpose page description language used in the business of desktop and electronic publishing. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.EPS
member.summary: Files with EPS extension essentially describe an Encapsulated PostScript language program that describes the appearance of a single page. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.ODG
member.summary: The ODG file format is used by Apache OpenOffice's Draw application to store drawing elements as a vector image. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.SVG
member.summary: An SVG file is a Scalar Vector Graphics file that uses XML based text format for describing the appearance of an image. Learn more about this file format here.

member.name: F:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.FileType.PICT
member.summary: The PICT file format is a meta-format that can be used for both bitmap images and vector images.

member.name: T:GroupDocs.Parser.Options.PageRenderInfo
member.summary: Represents the information of how a page is rendered.

remarks.para: Some documents (spreadsheets, for example) are not possible to render a page as a single image. For those documents a page is rendered as a set of tiles. These tiles are placed in the rectangular table.
and represent the total number of rows and columns of this table. If document page is rendered to the single image these properties are equal to 1.

member.summary: Provides the options which are used for text extraction.

remarks.para: An instance of class is used as parameter in and methods. See the usage examples there.

It's used to specify the raw mode of text extraction. A text in this mode is extracted in a non-accurate way but faster than in the standard mode. If the raw mode doesn't support the document format, then this parameter is ignored and the standard mode is used.

member.name: T:GroupDocs.Parser.Data.PageTextArea
member.summary: Represents a page text area which is used to represent a text value in the parsing by template or parsing form functionality.

remarks.para: An instance of class is used as return value of the following methods:
Also an instance of class is used as value of property.
See the usage examples there.

The text area can be single or composite. In the first case it contains a text which is bounded by a rectangular area. In the second case it contains other text areas; text and table properties are calculated by child text areas.
